div1.p: A CURE FOR THE HEART-ACHE, A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS, AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN
By THOMAS MORTON, Esq. AUTHOR OF COLUMBUS, ZORINSKI, WAY TO GET MARRIED, AND CHILDREN IN THE WOOD.
DUBLIN: Printed by P. WOGAN, Old Bridge. 1797.

div1.head: PROLOGUE,
div1.byline: WRITTEN BY T. W. FITZGERALD, Esq. Spoken by Mr. Macready.

sp.l: WHEN invalids possess both faith and wealth,
They'll find a nostrum to restore their health;
A panacea advertis'd to cure
Each ill the human body can endure.
But our bold Author claims a nobler art,
And advertises to relieve—the heart.
So many patients he expects to see,
That I'm appointed as his deputy.
Now, then, your mental maladies explain,
And I'll remove or mitigate the pain.
Does love or jealousy your peace molest,
Revenge inflame, ambition gnaw your breast?
For jealousy, a sovereign balm behold,—
The husband's certain cure, a pill of gold;
This dose, administer'd with prudent care,
Dispels at once the frailties of the fair;
Deprives the proctor of his crim. con. fee,
And tunes the chord that jar'd to harmony.
Should love torment some Romeo's heated brain,
Or agonize a Juliet's breast with pain,
Let them my potent remedy apply,—
The maid shall cease to pine, the youth to sigh;
Gold shall restore each drooping lover's health,
And passion sind a substitute in wealth.
But let not ill-tim'd ridicule degrade
What Heav'n, when well applied, a blessing made.
To foster merit, wheresoever found,
And with improvement cheer a country round;
To feed the hungry, and to clothe the poor,
And send the beggar happy from the door;
To mitigate the horrors of despair,
And make the family of want our care;
To succour genius, drooping in distress,
Making the business of our lives to bless.
When the rich man can such employment find,
We wish his purse as ample as his mind.
For one poor patient I've an anxious fear;
And you must be his kind physician here.
Our Author has to night so much at stake,
He finds his throbbing heart inclin'd to ache!
But should his play a lib'ral audience please,
Your warm applause will set his heart at ease.

div1.head: A CURE FOR THE HEART-ACHE, A COMEDY.

div3.head: SCENE I.

stage.hi: A Farm Yard. House on one Side, a neat Flower-Garden on the other. The Bells of a Team jingling.

sp.speaker: FRANK
sp.p: WOYH! Whoh! Smiler! (Enters.) So Feyther be not come home from the Nabob's house yet. Eh! bean't that sister Jessy, in her garden, busy among the poseys?—Sister Jessy!

div3.stage: Enter JESSY from the Garden, a watering-pot in her hand.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Ah, Frank! so soon returned from Gloucester? have you sold the corn?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: And how did you like the town? you were never there before?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Loike it! I don't know how I loiked it, not I; L zomehow cou'dn't zee the town for the housen: desperate zight of 'em, to be sure.—But Jessy, you who went to Lunnun Town to take in your larning, can tell me, be there as many houses in Lunnun?

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: A hundred times the number.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And do your 'squires there, like Sir Hubert Stanley, and the Nabob here, keep fine coaches?

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Yes, Frank; there are some thousands round St. James's Gate.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: St. James's Geat! Dong it; it wou'd be worth a poor man's while to stand and open that geat.—Pray you, where do that geat lead to?

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: The road to preferment, Frank.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ecod, if your road to preferment be so cramm'd wi' your coaches and great folk, no wonder a poor man be run down when he tries to get a bit.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You seem to be in terrible good spirits, Jessy.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: I have reason, Frank. I have just received a letter from my dear Edward, who has left London on business with his father, Mr. Rapid, and will be here to day.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I suppose it to be a desperate long letter, and cruel sweet. Full of kisses and voluntines.— Nine sheets, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Hardly nine words. The truth is, that Edward, tho' handsome, generous, and I hope sincere, is impatient and hasty to a degree that—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
Hasty! What then? when a man be on the road to do good, he can't go too fast, I say.— Bean't that Feyther coming thro' Wheat Ash? he have been drinking and gamestring all good Sunday night wi' Nabob's servants,—how whitish and deadly bad he do look. He us'd to be as comely and handsome as either of us, wasn't he now? Do you know, Jessy, at church yesterday, Sir Hubert, looking round, as he always do to see if his tenants be there, missed Feyther, and gave me such a desperate look, that I dropt prayer book out of my hand; and truly when Feyther do go to church I be always sham'd he never knows where to fin the collect—never—I'm sure it be not my fault, he be so full of prodigality—
never son set Feyther better example than I do's mine; what can I do more for 'un? it would not be becoming in me to leather Feather, would it, Jessy.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Here he comes, I'll return to my garden— to converse with him is to me dreadful; for, while my breast rises with indignation at his conduct as a man, it sinks again in pity for the misfortunes of a parent.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Now that's just like I—I feels as if I should like to lick 'un, and cry all the time—But what will be the end on't, Jessy?

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Ruin, inevitable ruin!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Well don't thee be cast down—thee knows I be cruel kind to thee; at meals I always gis thee the desperate nice bits, and if thy lover prove false hearted, or Feyther should come to decay, I be a terrible strong lad, I'll work for thee fra sunrise to down, and if any one offer to harm thee, I'll fight for thee till I die.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Thanks, my good lad! thanks, dear brother.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: As nice a bit of a sister that, as in all country round.

div3.stage: Enter FARMER OATLAND (dressed in a compound of rusticity and fashion.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: Ba viamo tutti tra.—Dom it, this be what I call loife! Have you sold the wheat?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: How much?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Two load—Six and twenty pound.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: Exactly the trifle I lost last night.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: Take it to the Nabob's gentleman.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I were going Feyther, to the castle, to ge it to Sir Hubart's steward for rent.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: Rent, you bore! That for Sir Hubert. (snapping his fingers). Ah, Nabob's servants be the tippy.—Every thing be done by them so genteelly.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ecod you be done by them genteelly enough; I be sure that house have brought the country round to ruination. Before this Nabob came here wi' all his money and be domn'd to 'un, every thing were as peaceable and deceant as never was;— not a lawyer within ten miles; now there be three practising in village; and what's ameast as bad, there be three doctors; and the farmers so consated, drive about in their chay carts, eat lump sugar ev'ry day, and gi'balls.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And what's the upshot? why that they jig it away to country jail.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: Tezez vous! Let me see—Great cassino be ten o diamonds. Well then, I play—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Play! ecod, if you go on so, you mun work tho'.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: Next, I must take care of the speads.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No, Feyther, a spade mun take care o' you; By gol, here be Mr. Heartly, Sir Hubert's steward, now don't you be saucy to un, Feyther;— now do behave thyzelf—now that's a man, Feyther, do.

sp.speaker: Heartly.
sp.p: Good day, Farmer Oatland; how dost do, honest Frank?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Desperate pure, thank ye, sur.

sp.speaker: Heartly.
sp.p: Well, farmer, once more I have called respecting your arrear of rent—Three hundred pound is a long sum.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Three hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Heartly.
sp.p: And unless it be immediately discharged, Sir Hubert is resolved to—

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: That for Sir Hubert—He shall have his rent—Frank, send your sister Jessy to the Nabob's, he'll let me have the money.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No! I won't—What business have sister at such a desperate prodigal place. Na, na, I'll go myzelf.

sp.speaker: Heartly.
sp.p: You are in the right, honest Frank.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yes, sur, I always am.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: Ugh! you vulgar mongrel—Well, desire the Nabob's gentleman to desire the Nabob to let me have three hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: He won't gi' thee a brass farthing.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: Sir Hubert shall have his money— Ha! ha! ha! my notion is, he wants it sad enough, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Heartly.
sp.p: Sirrah!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Don't you mind 'un, sur, don't ye, he be's intosticated. Dong thee behave thyself.

sp.speaker: Oatld.
sp.p: Silence, you hound! and obey!—Bon jour, Mr. Steward,—I'll to bed—'Pon honor, I must cut champagne, it makes me so narvous —Sir Hubert shall have his money, let that satisfy,—Follow me, cur.

sp.speaker: Heartly.
sp.p: Sad doings, Frank.

div3.stage: (FRANK shakes his head and follows OATLAND

div3.head: SCENE II—

stage.hi: A Room in the Nabob's house

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Good Mr. Bronze, have you been at Sir Hubert Stanley's?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Is Charles Stanley arrived?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: No, ma'am; but he is hourly expected.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Do they say he is well—quite recovered?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p:
I don't know, ma'am—upon my soul—I beg pardon, but really the Baronet's house is horrid vulgar, compared to your uncle's, the Nabob's here; I peeped thro' my glass into an old hall, and beheld fifty paupers at dinner, such wretches! and the Baronet himself walking round the table to see them properly fed.—How damn'd low!—Ugh! I would bett a rump and dozen our second table is more genteelerer than Sir Hubert's own—but I must away, for we expect the rich Miss Vortex—I beg pardon; but your name and the Nabob's
daughter being the same, we call her the rich, to distinguish—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: And you do wisely—no term of distinction cou'd possibly be more significant or better understood by the world, than that you have adopted.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Hope no offence, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: None, Bronze, go in.—

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: The last man on earth to offend a fine woman.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: The rich Miss Vortex—most true.—But now my dear Charles Stanley is return'd, I claim the superior title of the Happy. Oh! Charles, when we parted last at Spa; how great the contrast; thy animated form was prison'd in the icy fetters of disease; thy pale and quiv'ring lip refused a last adieu;—But ah! a smile that seemed borrowed from a seraph who waited to bear thee up to Heaven, swore for thee everlasting love. That smile supported me in solitude,—but to solitude I have now bade adieu, and to be near the lord of my heart, have again enter'd this house, the palace of ruinous luxury and licentious madness; but here comes its whimsical proprietor.

div3.stage: Enter Mr. VORTEX with a paper in his hand, attended by black and white servants.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Sublime!—oh, the fame of this speech will spread to Indostan. Eh!—don't I smell the pure air in this room? Oh! you villains! would you destroy me, throw about the perfumes for legislative profundity; for fancy and decoration,—'tis a speech.—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: What speech is it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Vortex
sp.p: Ah! Ellen—why my maiden speech in Parliament—it will alarm all Europe—I'll speak it to you.—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: No, my dear uncle, not just now—I hear you've been ill.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh! very—a strange agitation at my heart, and such a whizzing and spinning in my head—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: I hope you've had advice?—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh, yes, I've had them all.—One physician told me it was caused by too brilliant and effervescent a genius;—the next said, it was the scurvy; —a third, it proceeded from not eating pepper to a melon;—another had the impudence to hint it was only little qualms that agitated some gentlemen who had made fortunes in India;—one recommended a sea voyage,—another a flannel night-cap;—one prescrib'd water,—the other brandy; but, however they all agreed in this essential point, that I'm not to be contradicted, but have my way in every thing.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: An extremely pleasant prescription, certainly. But under these circumstances do you hold it prudent, uncle, to become a parliamentary Orator? I believe a little gentle contradiction is usual in that House.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I know it—but if you will hear my speech, you will see how I manage—I begin —Sir—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Your daughter, sir, is arrived from Town.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Thank you cousin for this relief.—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Zounds! I'm not to be interrupted.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: She is here, sir.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: My dear Nabob, uncommon glad to see you. Ah! Ellen; what, tired of seclusion and a cottage?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: I hope, cousin, I am welcome to you.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Certainly; you know we are uncommon glad to see any body in the country—but, my dear Nabob, you don't inquire about the opening of our town-house.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I was thinking of my speech.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: The most brilliant house-warming— uncommon full, above a thousand people—every body there.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Pray, cousin, do you then visit every body?

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Certainly, they must ask me.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Must! I shou'd imagine that wou'd depend on inclination.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Inclination! psha! I beg your pardon; but you are really uncommon ignorant my dear. They must ask me, I tell you.—Now suppose a Dutchess rash enough to shut me from her parties; —very well.—She names a night.—I name the same, and give an entertainment greatly surpassing her's in splendour and profusion.—What is the consequence? —why, that her rooms are as deserted as an Ex-minister's levee, and mine cramm'd to suffocation with her Grace's most puissant and noble friends.—Ha! ha! my dear Ellen, the court of St. James's run after a good supper as eagerly as the court of Aldermen.—Ha! ha! your being in this country, Nabob, was thought quite charming.—A host not being at home to receive his guests is uncommon new and elegant, isn't.—Here we improve, my dear, on ancient hospitality—those little memorandums, Nabob, will give you an idea of the sort of thing.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: "March."—Oh! that's a delightful month, when Nature produces nothing, and every thing is forc'd.—Let me see—" 50 quarts of green peas at five guineas a quart,"—that was pretty well:—"500 peaches"—at what?—" a guinea each."—Oh! too cheap.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: 'Tis very true; but I assure you I tried every where to get them dearer, but cou'd not.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: And I suppose the new white sattin furniture was all spoil'd.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Oh! entirely—and the pier glasses shivered to pieces so delightfully.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Well, I hope you had the whole account put in the papers?

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Certainly, else what would have been the use of giving the fete. Then the company; such charming eccentricity, such characters out of character.—We had a noble Peer bowing for custom to his shop, and an Alderman turning over the music leaves for the celebrated Soprano; an Orator's lady detailing her hnsband's three hours speech in Parliament, and the Orator himself describing how puppets are managed at the Fantoccini; we had grandmothers making assignations with boys, and the children of Israel joining the host of Pharaoh.—Oh! my dear Miss Vortex, why don't you partake in these charming scenes?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: My dear Miss Vortex, six suppers would annihilate my fortune.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Oh true, I forgot your uncommon small fortune. But I don't think it much signifies. I swear, people of fashion in town seem to do as well without money, as with it. You might be successful at play. There are points to be learnt, which certainly do not give you the worst of the game. Come, will you be my protegée?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Excuse me, coussn, I dare say I ought to be covered with blushes, when I own a vulgar detestation of the character of a female gamester, and I must decline the honor of your introduction to the haut ton till at least they have justice on their side.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: An uncommon odd girl, Nabob.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Heavens! to what state of abject degradation must fashionable society be reduced, when officers of police are as much dreaded by ladies in the purlieus of St. James's, as they are by cut purses in the wretched haunts of St. Giles.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: For shame, Ellen, to censure your own sex.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: No, madam, I am its advocate, and in that sex's name protest an abhorrence of those women, who do not consider any thing shameful but to be ashamed of any thing; whose resemblance to nature and innocence exists but in their nakedness, and to whom honour is only known as a pledge at a gaming table.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Did you ever hear, Nabob?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I did not hear a word she said; I was thinking of my speech.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: A pert, Gothic, low-bred creature! But her contemptible fortune suits uncommon well with her grovelling ideas.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Don't talk of her fortune, it always makes my poor head worse. You know at the time I gave her five thousand pounds in lieu of what I called her expectations, I had in my hands an enormous sum of her's. O dear! I'm afraid the doctor was right—ah! mine are certainly East India qualms—I wonder if giving her fifty thousand back again wou'd do my heart any good.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: What! my dear Nabob? I declare you quite shock me.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh conscience!

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Conscience! he! he! a thing so uncommon vulgar, a thing so completely chausseed; besides, yon know very well it is absolutely impossible to exist under 20,000l. a-year.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: That's very true.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Some people certainly do contrive to grub on with ten thousand, but how they do it is to me miraculous; then think of your intention of marrying me to the son of your great rival the baronet; think of his borough.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Ah! very true.—Conscience avaunt; I have made a motion on matrimony to Sir Hubert.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: And young Stanley's arrival; Oh! what a sweet youth!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh! what a sweet borough interest! But I am glad your heart is interested.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Heart interested! Lud, how can you suspect me of so uncommon vulgar a sensation. I trust my joy is occasioned by ideas more becoming a woman of fashion.—I am charm'd because his fortune is large, his family ancient; and because my marriage will render all my female friends so uncommon miserable; and because I suspect that Ellen met young Stanley at Spa, and that she dares aspire to—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I wish she were out of the house.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: No—she shall stay to witness my triumph.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Shall stay.—I'm not to be contradicted, you know—my physicians—

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Certainly not, my dear Nabob; but I may recommend; I'm sure no physician would object to your taking advice. Ah! does Ellen love you as I do?—will she listen to your speech as I intend to do?—would she throw away thousands for you in a night, as I do?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Very true! very true!

div3.head: SCENE III.—

stage.hi: A Pleasure Ground, and View of an ancient Castle.

div3.stage: Enter four Servants dress'd in old fashion'd liveries, then Sir HUBERT STANLEY and HEARTLY.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Good Heartly, is all prepar'd for my boy's reception, his favourite study on the southern battlement?—Are his dogs train'd—his hunters well condition'd?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: To say truth, Sir Hubert, the castle has been all day in quarrel, each servant claiming the right of exclusive attendance on his dear young master.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: I thank their honest loves. He writes me he is well, good Heartly; quite well.—Ha! the village bells proclaim my boy's arrival.—Dost thou hear the people's shouts?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Aye, and it revives my old heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: These welcomes are the genuine effusions of love and gratitude.—Spite of this Nabob's arts, you see how my loving neighbours respect me.
Where is my boy?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Not yet arriv'd, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: These rejoicings are for the Nabob's daughter, who is just come from London.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Indeed! (pecvishly) Well, well.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My young master will alight privately at Oatland farm, and walk through the park.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: The Nabob's daughter?—Well, let it pass.—Heartley, what said farmer Oatland?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Nothing but what profligacy and insolence dictated—he desied your power, and sent to the Nabob.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Ungrateful man! let a distres be issued. —Hold; no, no.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir Hubert, he is undeserving your lenity.—Besides, sir, your mortgagee, Mr. Rapid, the wealthy taylor, will be here to-day— the interest on the mortgage must be paid—some of your election bills remain unliquidated, and I fear without a surther mortgage—

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Don't torture. Pardon me, good old man.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Truly, Sir Hubert, what might have been effected with 5000l, some years ago, will now require ten—you must retrench your hospitable benevolence.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: My worthy steward, my head has long acknowledg'd the truth of your arithmetic—but my head could never teach it to my heart.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: And, sir, you may raise your rents.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Never, Heartley.—never.—What! shall the many suffer that I may be at ease!—But away with care—this is a moment devoted to extasy —this is the hour a doating father is to clasp an only child, who, after combating with disease and death, returns triumphant to his arms in lusty health and manhood.—Ah! he approaches; 'tis my boy—Dost thou not see him in the beechen avenue. —Dull old man, advance thine hand thus,— (putting his hand over his forehead)—See how his eyes wander with delight, and renovate the pictures of his youth.—Ah! now he sees his father, and sties like lightning.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: My honour'd—my lov'd father!

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p:
Rise to my heart.—Stand off, and let my eyes gloat upon thee—thou art well—Thy arm,
good Heartley.—Nay, do not weep, old Honesty, 'twill infect me.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Ah! my excellent old friend—in health I hope?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Aye, good master, and this day will make me young again.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Dear father, already must I become a suitor to you.—Passing Oatland farm, I found his lovely daughter Jessy in tears, occasion'd by her father's inability to pay his rent. I dried them with a promise— (Heartley shakes his head, and Sir Hubert averts his face).—Ha! your brow is clouded with unhappiness;—pray, sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Good Heartley, leave us— (Exeunt HEARTLEY and Servants.)—Charles, so mix'd is the cup of life, that this day, the happiest thy old father can e'er hope to see, is dash'd with bitterness and sorrow, boy. I've been a very unthrift to thee.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Oh, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Listen to me.—You have heard how my father kept alive the benevolent hospitality that once distinguish'd old England, and I not finding in modern ethics aught likely to improve either the morals or happiness of mankind, determin'd to persevere in the ways of my fathers. Soon after you went abroad the adjoining estate was purchased by an East Indian, groaning under wealth produc'd by groans. Like the viper, after collecting in the warm sunshine his bag of venom, he came to the abode of peace and innocence, and disseminated his poison. But mark me—think me not so unjust, boy, as with random slander to censure any body of men. No, thank heaven; there are numbers whom Providence, in addition to the power, has added the will, to render wealth a blessing to all around them.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: You are ever just and liberal.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p:
But for this vile exception, this Mr. Vortex, I tell thee, riot, contention, indolence, and vice succeeded. I struggled against this mischies, which spurr'd him on to oppose me in my election. This contest (I trust, Charlea, you think
the dignity of your family demanded it)—this contest, I say, obliged me to mortgage my estate to a considerable amount; and I fear, boy, even that will not suffice.—Dost thou not blame thy father?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Blame, sir? my fortune, nay, my life is held but to promote your happiness.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Glorious boy! then all will be well again—thy estate restor'd, thy wealth enlarg'd

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: By marriage, Charles.—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Marriage, sir!—To conceal the passion that triumphs here were but to deceive a father, and injure the bright excellence I love. When I was ill at Spa, the votaries of pleasure avoided me as the harbinger of melancholy, and I was despis'd as a thing passing into oblivion by all but one fair creature. I obtain'd an opportunity to thank her for the charitable pity her eye had beam'd on me. Love soon kindled his torch at Pity's altar, for I found in Miss Vortex such excellence—

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Miss Vortex, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: From India?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: She that is now propos'd for your alliance.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: And waits your arrival in the neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Oh! let me haste to her.—Yet hold! Frank Oatland attends to hear your determination.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: At present, Charles, I cannot grant your suit.— (CHARLES beckons in FRANK)—Young man, tell your father the law must take its course. When I see in him symptoms of contrition and amendmert, I may restore him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Thank ye,—thank ye, sur.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: How came this distress to fall on him?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
Why, sur, he went on farmering pretty tightish, didn't he, sur? till he keep't company wi' Nabob's sarvants; then all of a sudden, he took to the gentlemen line. I conceats, sur, he did'nt
much understand the trim on't, for the gentleman line didn't answer at all. I hope your honour bean't angry wi' I for speaking to young 'Squire; your worship do know I were a bit of a playfellow wi' un, and we followed our studies together.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ect, sur, we went through our letters— and a-b, ab—c-b, eb—there somehow I stuck, and 'Squire went clean away into abreviation and abcmination; and then I never cou'd take much to your pens, they be so cruel small; now a pitchfork do fit my hand so desperate kindly as never was.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Ha! ha! Come my boy, you'll want refreshment.

div3.stage: Exit. FRANK bows, and is going.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: What honest Frank, will you not walk with me to the castle?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: If your honour be so gracious.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Nay, wear your hat.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: O dear! O dear! what a pity nobody do see I.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Come, brother student, your hand.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: My hand! Lord dong it, only think o'I.

div3.head: SCENE I.
div3.stage: Enter two Waiters with Luggage, meeting Bronze.

sp.speaker: Ist Wait.
sp.p: Coming Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Zounds why don't you come? why don't all of you come, eh!

sp.speaker: Brenze.
sp.p: Waiter, who are these people?

sp.speaker: Ist. Wait.
sp.p: I don't know, Mr. Bronze.—The young one seems a queer one—he jump'd out of the mail, ran into the kitchen, whipp'd the turnspit into a gallop, and bade him keep moving; and tho' not a minute in the house, he had been in every room, from the garret to the cellar.

sp.speaker: 2d. Wait.
sp.p: Father and son I understand.—The name on the luggage, I see, is Rapid.

sp.speaker: Bronza.
sp.p: Rapid! (aside). Perhaps it is my old master, the great taylor, and his harum-scarum son —I'll observe.

sp.speaker: Ist. Wait.
sp.p: Here he comes, full dash, and the old man trotting after him like a terrier.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Come along dad—push on my dear dad. —Well, here we are—keep moving.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Moving! zounds, haven't I been moving all night in the mail coach, to please you?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Mail! famous thing, isn't it? Je up! whip over counties in a hop, step and jump—dash along.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Od rot such hurry scurry doings, I say. Here have I ground my old bones all night in the mail, to be eight hours before my appointment with Sir Hubert Stanley, and now I must sit biting my fingers—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Biting your singers! no, no—I'll sind you something to do.—Come, we'll-keep moving.

div3.stage: Takes his father by the arm, who resisits.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I beg leave—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: No prosing—To the point—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: For shame—don't interrupt the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Gently, dad—dash away, sir.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: A servant of Sir Hubert Stanley has been enquiring for. Mr. Rapid.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Push on!

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: And expects him at the castle.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That will do—push off—brush—run!
That's the thing—keep moving—I say, dad!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: What do you say, Neddy?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Neddy! dam it, don't call me Neddy. I hate to be call'd Neddy.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Well, I won't.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That's settled—I say—what's your business with Sir Hubert?—Some secret, eh?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I won't tell you. Oh no— a bill he owes me for making his clothes and liveries.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Pugh! he's a ready-money man. I never made a bill out for him in my life—It won't do.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Well then, sit down, and I'll tell you (they sit). Can you sit still a moment?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: To be sure I can—now tell me briefly—briefly.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Indeed I will not—You must know—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Aye—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: You must know—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Zounds! you've said that twice—now don't say it again.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Well, I won't.—You must know—'tis a very long story.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Then I'll not trouble you.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I thought so. And pray what might induce you to come with me?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Won't tell him of Jessy.—Oh, as we had given up trade, left off stitching—you know my way—I like to push on—change the scene, that's all—keep moving.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Moving! (yawns). Oh, my poor old bones! Waiter, bring me a night-gown.
sp.stage: (Waiter helps him on with a night-gown—he lays his coat on a chair).

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What are yon at, dad?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Going to take a nap on that sofa.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: A nap—pugh!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Zounds! I've no comfort of my life with you.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Say no more.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: But I will, tho'—hurry, hurry—od rabbit it, I never get a dinner that's half dressed; and as for a comfortable sleep, I'm sure—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: You sleep so slow.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Sleep slow! I'll sleep as slow as I please; so at your peril disturb me. Sleep slow indeed!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Now to visit Jessy. Waiter!

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Sar!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That's right—sir—short—you're a fine fellow.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Yes, sar.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Does Farmer Oatland live hereabouts?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Yes, sar.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: How far?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Three miles.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Which way?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: West.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That will do—get me a buggy.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Yes, sar.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Oh, if my old dad had left off business as some of your flashy taylors to, I might have kept a curricle, and liv'd like a man. Is the buggy ready?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: No, sar.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: But to cut the shop with paltry five thousand.—Is the buggy ready?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: No, sar.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Or to have dashed to Jessy in a curricle. —Is the buggy ready?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p:
To have flank'd along a pair of blood things at sixteen miles an hour. (Puts himself in the act of driving, and sits on the chair where OLD RAPID left his coat—springs from it again) What the devil's that? Zounds! something has run into my back. I'll bet a hundred 'tis a needle in Father's pocket. Confound it! what does he carry needles now sor? (Searches the pocket.) Sure enough, here it is—one end stuck into a letter, and the other into my back, I believe. Curse it! Eh! what's this? (Reads) "To Mr. Rapid—Free—
Hubert Stanley." Ha, ha, ha, here's dad's secret— Now for it! (Reads very quick). "Sir Hubert Stanley will expect to see Mr. Rapid at the Castle, and wou'd be glad to extend the mortgage, which is now 50,000l." What's this? (Reads again)—"Extend the mortgage, "which is now 50,000l to seventy." Fifty thousand! huzza! 'tis so—my old dad worth fifty thousand—perhaps seventy —perhaps—I'll—no—I'll—

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: The buggy's ready, sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Dare to talk to me of a buggy, and I'll—

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Perhaps you wou'd prefer a chaise and pair?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: No, I'll have a chaise and twelve. Abscond! (Exit Waiter.) I must—I must keep moving.—I must travel for improvement. First I'll see the whole of my native country, its agriculture and manufactories. That, I think, will take me full four days and a half. Next I'll make the tour of Europe; which, to do properly, will I dare say, employ three weeks or a month. Then, returning as completely vers'd in foreign manners and languages as the best of them, I'll make a push at high life. In the first circles I'll keep moving. Fifty thousand! perhaps more—perhaps—ho!

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: You can't come in.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: I tell you I will come in.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Will come in!—that's right—push on, whoever you are.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: I thought so. How do you do, Mr. Rapid? Don't you remember Bronze, your father's foreman, when you were a boy?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Ah, Bronze! how do you do, Bronze? Any thing to say, Bronze? Keep moving. Do you know, Bronze, by this letter I have discover'd that my father is worth—how much, think you?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Perhaps ten thousand.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Push on.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Twenty.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Push on.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Thirty.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Keep moving.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Forty.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Fifty—perhaps—sixty—seventy—oh! I;ll tell you. He has lent 50,000l. on mortgage to an old Baronet.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Sir Hubert St.—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I know his name as well as you do.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Here's news for my master! Well, Sir, what do you mean to do?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Do! Push on—become a man of fashion, to be sure.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: What wou'd you say, if I were to get you introduced to a Nabob?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: A Nabob! Oh! some flash-in-the-pan chap.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Oh, no!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What, one of your real, genuine, neat as imported, Nabobs?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Yes; Mr. Vortex.—Did you never hear of him.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: To be sure I have. But will you?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Ah! but will you do it directly?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Then push off—Stop—stop—I beg your pardon—it cuts me to the heart to stop any man, because I wish every body to keep moving. But won't dad's being a taylor, make an objection?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: No; as you never went out with the pattern-books.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Oh yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: That's aukward.—But you never operated?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What do you say?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: I say you never—
sp.stage: (describes in action the act of sewing.)

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Oh! yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: That's unlucky.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Very melancholy indeed!

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: I have it. Suppose I say you are merchants.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: My dear fellow, sink the taylor, and I'll give you a hundred.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Will you? Thank you.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Now push off.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: But don't be out of the way.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Me! Bless you, I'm always in the way.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Don't move.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Yes, I must move a little—away you go— (pushes Bronze off). Huzza! now to awake old dad. (Exit, and returns with OLD RAPID.) Come along, dad.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Yes, sir—yes, sir— I'll measure you directly—I'll measure you directly.

sp.speaker: R. Rap.
sp.p: He's asleep.—Awake!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: What's the matter, eh? What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What's the matter! I've found fifty thousand in that letter?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Indeed! (opens the letter eagerly). Ah! Neddy, have you found out—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I have—that you are worth—how much?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Why, since what's past—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Never mind what's past.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I've been a fortunate man. My old partner us'd to say, Ah! you are lucky, Rapid. Your needle always sticks in the right place.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: No, not always (shrugging). But how much?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Why as it must out, there are fifty thousand lent on mortgage.—Item, fifteen thousand in the Consols—Item—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Never mind the Items.—The total, my dear dad—the total.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: What do you think of a plum?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: A plum! Oh, sweet, agreeable, little, short word!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Besides seven hundred and ninety—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Never mind the odd money—that will do. But how came you so rich, dad? Dam'me, you must have kept moving.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Why, my father, forty years ago, left me five thousand pounds; which, at compound interest, if you multiply—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: No; you have multiplied it famously. It's my business to reduce it (aside). Now, my dear dad, in the first place never call me Neddy.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Why, what must I call you?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Ned—short—Ned.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Ned—short—Ned.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Ned! O Ned!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That will do. And, in the next place, sink the taylor. Whatever you do, sink the taylor.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Sink the taylor! What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I've news for you. We are going to be introduced to Mr. Vortex, the rich Nabob.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: You don't say so! Huzza; it will be the making of us.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: To be sure. Such fashion! such stile!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Aye, and such a quantity of liveries, and—Oh dear me!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I forgot I had left off business.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Business! Confound it! Now, pray keep the taylor under, will you? I'll—I'll send an express to London (runs to the table).

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: An express for what?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I don't know.—

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: The bill of fare, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Bring it here (reads). Turbots— Salmon—Soles—Haddock—Beef—Mutton— Veal—Lamb—Pork—Chickens—Ducks— Turkeys—Puddings—Pyes.—Dress it all— that's the short way.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: All!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Every bit.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p:
No, no, nonsense.—The short way
indeed! Come here, sir.—Let me see— (reads). "Um—Um—Ribs of beef."—That's a good thing; —I'll have that.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Ribs of beef, sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Are they the short ribs?

sp.speaker: Waiter
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That's right.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: What liquor would your honour like?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Spruce beer.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Very well, sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I must have some clothes.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I'm sure that's a very good coat▪

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Waiter!—I must have a dashing coat for the Nabob. Is there a rascally taylor any where near you?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Yes, sir;—there are two close by
sp.stage: (Father and Son look at each other)

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Umph! Then tell one of them to send me some clothes.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Sir, he must take your measure.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: To be sure he must.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Oh true! I remember the fellows do measure you somehow with long bits of—Well— send for the scoundrel.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Oh, for shame of yourself! I've no patience.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Like you the better.—Hate patience as much as you do, ha! ha!—Must swagger a little.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Ah! I am too fond of you, I am, Ned. Take my fortune; but only remember this—By the faith of a man I came by it honestly—and all I ask is, that it may go as it came.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Certainly. But we must keep moving, you know.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Well, I don't care if I do take a bit of a walk with you.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Bit of a walk! Dam'me, we'll have a gallop together. Come along dad.—Push on dad.

div3.head: SCENE II.—
div3.stage: Enter Mr. VORTEX, ELLEN, and Miss VORTEX.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Married to Charles Stanley! You, Madam?

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Yes, I.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: I'll not believe it.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Well, I vow that's uncommon comic. And why not, my forsaken cousin?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: First, madam, I know Charles Stanley would only form so sacred an alliance where his affections pointed out the object. Secondly, I feel those affections to be mine.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Thirdly, an inconstant swain was a thing never heard of; and, to conclude, pray peruse that letter—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Sir Hubert Stanley informs Mr. Vortex that his son embraces with eager joy the proposals for his marriage with Mr. Vortex's daughter.(Drops the letter). Then every thing is possible. Oh love!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Nay, Don't you abuse poor Cupid—his conduct has been perfectly parliamentary. Self interest has made the little gentleman move over to the other side, that's all

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Heavens! should this be—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Young Mr. Stanley, sir.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Young Mr. Stanley, sir.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: My soul sinks within me.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Upon my honour, my dear, you had better retire.—Your agitation.—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: I thank you, madam (going.) Hold.— No;—with your permission I'll remain

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Just as you please. What a triumph! Oh, how uncommon delicious!

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Now heart be firm!
sp.stage: (Retires from the front of the stage).

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: How he's struck!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.p: What can this mean? (aside). Ma— mad—madam—the confusion that—that—that—

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: I must cheer him with a smile.
sp.stage: (During this ELLEN advances to the front of the stage, so as to leave Miss VORTEX between her and STANLEY.)

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Ah! what heaven of brightness breaks in upon me! Lovely Miss Vortex, can I believe my happiness? Will those arms receive me? (Miss VORTEX, thinking this a addressed to her, opens her arms; STANLEY rushes past her to ELLEN.) My Ellen!

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Oh, Charles, the sufferings my heart underwent this moment, and the joy it now feels is such, I cannot speak.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Nabob! Nabob!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: The matter! won't you resent this?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh dear! not I.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Will you bear an insult?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: My physicians order me not to mind being insulted at all: nothing is to provoke me.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Provoke you!—If I were a man, I would—Oh!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I don't like his looks,—he seems a desperate—

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: What do you mean to do?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Why, as this is a very extraordinary case—

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I think it best to—adjourn
sp.stage: (goes up the stage, Miss VORTEX follows).

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I perceive the mistake; but my heart confess'd but one Miss Vortex—I thought the name, like the superior virtues you adorn it with, attach'd alone to Ellen. The embarrassments of my paternal estate demanded a marriage with a woman of fortune.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: What do I hear?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Why this alarm?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Alarm! Must not those words terrify which separate me from you for ever?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: What means my Ellen?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Oh, Stanley, hear me. On my return to England, Mr. Vortex, to whom the care of my property was entrusted, was ever pressing on my mind the difficulty of recovering my father's India possessions. Each messenger that arrived from you, confirmed the melancholy tale, that my Stanley was sinking into an early grave. Oh! what then was fortune or the world to me? I sought out solitude, and willingly assigned to Mr. Vortex what he called my expectations, for five thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Yet you shall be mine.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: No, Charles, I will not bring you poverty. I'll return to solitude, and endeavour to teach this lesson to my heart, "That it will be joy enough to know that Stanley is well and happy."

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Stay, Ellen—think deeply before you consign the man that loves you to certain misery.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: True—in a few hours let me see you again. The opposing agitations my mind has suffered unfit me for further conversation.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: In a few hours, then, you'll allow me to see you?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Allow you to see me!—Oh! Stanley, farewell!

div3.stage: Mr. and Miss VORTEX come forward.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Now speak.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: We had better pair off.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: No—speak with spirit.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I will.—Sir, I cannot help saying, that every man, that is, every man of honor—

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: That's right!—say that again.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: That every man of honor—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Well, sir?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: It—is—the—the—best judge of his own actions.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I perfectly agree with you—and wish you a good morning.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: So, then, I'm to be insulted, despis'd and laugh'd at, and no duel is to take place— nobody is to be kill'd— my tender heart is to feel no satisfaction—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I fight!—Do you consider the preciousness of a legislator's life?
"A county suffers when a Member bleeds."

sp.speaker: Bronze
sp.p: Oh, sir, such news!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: What, is Parliament convened?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: No, sir; but I have found out that the Baronet is—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: What of him?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Ruin'd!

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Well! that's some satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Bronze
sp.p: I met at the inn the Mr. Rapid's, merchants I formerly lived with, who have a large mortgage on his estate, and he wants to borrow more—So, sir, I told them I was sure my master would be proud to fee them at Bangalore-Hall, because I thought, sir.—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I know—I have it. I'll shew them every attention; and if I can but get hold of the mortgage, I'll—

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Oh! uncommon charming!
Now do you go and write a note, and say we will wait on them.—Ah! use policy instead of pistols, and I would fight any man—for, as I say in my speech, "Policy, Mr. Speaker, is—"

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Exactly, Nabob—but I must write the letter, you know. Is the young merchant handsome?

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Yes, madam.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: So much the better.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: You see, Bronze, the turn I give it is this—"Policy, Mr. Speaker, says I—"

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Very true, sir; but I believe my mistress calls—I attend you, madam.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Confound it! Will nobody hear my speech? then I'll speak it to myself.—"Policy, Mr. Speaker—"

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: How do you do, sur?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: What! interrupted again!—Approach, don't be afraid.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Lord, sur, I bean't afeard; Why should I;—I defies the devil and all his works.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: If this be what is called rough honesty, give me a little smooth-tongu'd roguery. I don't know you, fellow!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ees, sur, you do—I be's Frank Oatland.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Begone! I know notning of you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ees, sur, you do—I've a bit of a sister crll'd Jessy.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Eh! ah!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Dom um, he knaws me well enough now.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh! very true—Frank Oatland, aye! Well, good Frank, how is Jessy?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Charming, sur! charming!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Aye, that she is, lovely and charming, indeed! (aside)—And how are you, Frank?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I be's charming too, sur!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: But why don't Jessy visit my people here? I should be always happy to see her.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Should you, sur? Why, if I may be so bold as to ax, why, sur?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Because—because—she is—a—farmer Oatland's child.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: So be I, sur. How comes it, then, that you never axes I to your balls and ostentations? I can dance twice as long as sister can.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Cunning fellow this!—I must buy him. Well, Frank, what are your commands?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, sur, Feyther do command you to lend him three hundred pounds—no, sur, I mean he supplicates.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Three hundred pounds?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
I'll tell you, sur, all about it.—You knaw, sur, Feyther have been knuckled out of a
most cruel sight of money by you at weagering and cards.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: By me, fellow! Do you think I associate with such reptiles?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ecod, it was either you or t'other gentleman.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: T'other gentleman!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I dan't knaw which be which, not I.— There be two of you.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Two of us!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ees; there be you—that be one;—and there be your gentleman—he do make the pair.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: The pair!—And have I been buying a hundred thousand pounds worth of respect for this? Have I become a Member to pair off with my valet?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ecod, and a comical pair you be!— T'other gentleman be a tightish, conceated sort of a chap enough; but you be a little—he! he!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Upon my soul, this is very pleasant— You are quite free and easy.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Quite, sur; quite. Feyther do tell I it be all the fashion.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: He does!—Then you may tell Feyther, that if he has lost his money at play, the winners won't give him sixpence to save him from starving, that be all the fashion.—By their distress the pretty Jessy will be more in my power, and then I can reinstate them in a farm upon terms (aside). Go, fellow! I shall not send your Father sixpence.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: The words I told um—the very words I told um.—Says I—"Feyther, he bean't the man will gi' thee a brass farthing. Dong it, he hasn't it here, says I"

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: You said so, did you?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ees—so you see, sur, what a desperate cute laid I be.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I'll set a trap for you, you dog— I'll have you in my power, however; I'll drop my purse—he'll take it—and then— (drops his purse)— A pair of us! I'll lay you by the heels, desperate cute as you are.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Poor Feyther, poor Sister, and poor I! Feyther will go broken-hearted, for sartain;—and then sister Jessy's coming to labour.—I can't bear the thought on't. Od dom thee! if I could but get hold of some of thy money, I'd teak care thee should not get it again.—Eh! (sees the purse, walks round it). Well, now, I declare that do look for all the world like a purse. How happy it would make poor Feyther and Sister! I conceats there wou'd be no harm just to touch it;— (takes it up 0 with caution;)—it be cruel tempting. Nobody do see I.—I wonder how it wou'd feel in my pocket (puts it with fear into his pocket). Wouns! how hot I be! Cruel warm to be sure. Who's that? Nobody.—Oh! I—I—l-u-d, lud! and I ha' gotten such a desperate ague all of a sudden,—and my heart do keep j—jump—jumping.—I believe I be going to die (falls into a chair). Eh!—Eh!— Mayhap it be this terrible purse. Dom thee, come out (throws it down.—After a pause) Ees, now I is better.—Dear me, quite an alteration.—My head doant spin about soa, and my heart do feel as light, and do so keep tittuping, tittuping, I can't help crying.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Now I have him.— (Sees the purse). What, he has not stole it, tho' his own Father's in want!—Here's a precious rascal for you!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Mr. Nabob, you have left your purse behind you (sobbing); and you ought to be asheamed of yourself, so you ought, to leave a purse in a poor lad's way, who has a Feyther and a Sister coming to starving.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: My purse! True; reach it me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Noa, thank you for nothing.—I've had it in my hand once.—Ecod, if having other people's money do make a man so hot, how desperate warm some folks mun be!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Warm,—foolish fellow! (wiping his forehead, and fanning himself with his hat). Fugh! quite a Bengal day, I declare.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Od dang it! how their wicked heads mun spin round!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Spin round! I never heard such a simpleton.—Spin, indeed! ha! ha! God bless my soul, I'm quite giddy! Oh Lord! Oh dear me! Help! help!

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: What's the matter, sir.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Only a little touch of my old complaint. —Send that fellow away.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Oh, this be t'other gentleman. Sur, I ha' gotten twenty-six pound that Feyther lost to you at gamestering.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: Where is it?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: In my pocket.

sp.speaker: Bronze.
sp.p: That's lucky! give it me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Gi' it thee! Ees, dom thee, come out, and I'll gi' it thee

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Begone!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I wish you both a good morning.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: What a dunderhead that is! To suppose that a little tenderness of conscience wou'd make a man's head turn round.—Pugh! 'tis impossible;—or how the devil wou'd the Lawyers sind their way from Westminster-hall? Giddy, indeed! Ha! ha!—Bronze, take care I don't fall.

div3.head: SCENE I.—
div3.stage: Enter OLD RAPID with a Letter, and a Servant following.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p:
What! a real letter from the real Nabob! —Dear me! where is Neddy?—Make my humble
duty to your master; proud to serve him—no—very proud to see him;—grateful for the honor of his custom—no—no—for his company.—I wish you a pleasant walk home, sir.—The Nabob coming here directly! Oh, dear me! where's Neddy—waiter!—
Do you know where my boy is?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Not a minute ago I saw him fighting in a field behind the house.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Fighting!—Oh, dear! where is he?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Here am I, dad.—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: What has been the matter?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Only a small rumpus;—went to peep at the castle,—pushing home,—the road had a bit of a circumbendibus,—hate corners,—so I jumped the hedge,—cut right across,—you know my way,— kept moving,—up came a farmer,—wanted to turn me back,—would not do,—tussled a bit,—carried my point,—came strait as an arrow.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Fie, fie!—But read that letter.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What, the Nabob coming here directly, and I in this pickle.—Waiter, are my clothes come home?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Why, the fellow gave his word—

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Yes, sir;—but what can you expect from a taylor?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That's very true.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Impudent rascal!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What the devil shall I do?—the most important moment of my life.—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: 'Tis unlucky.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Unlucky!—'tis perdition—annihilation —a misfortune that—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I can mend.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: By mending the coat.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: An excellent thought.—Come, help me off;—quick.—quick!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I always have a needle in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I know you have.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Now give it me.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What suffer my father to mend my coat?—No,—no;—not so bad as that neither.—As the coat must be mended,—damn it, I'll mend it.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Will you tho'?—Ecod, I should like to see you;—here's a needle ready threaded—and a thimble;—you can't think how I shall like to see you;—now don't hurry, that's a dear boy.
sp.stage: (YOUNG RAPID sits down, gathers his legs under him—OLD RAPID puts his spectacles on, and sits close to him, looking on.)

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Now mind, dad, when—Damn the needle!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: That's because you are in such a hurry.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: When the Nabob comes,—sink the taylor. —

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I will; but that's a long stitch.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Be sure you siak the taylor;—a great deal depends on the first impression;—you shall be reading a grave book with a melancholy air.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Then I wish I had brought down my book of bad debts;—that would have made me melancholy enough.

div3.stage: Enter Isr. and Miss VORTEX, who advance slowly, the Nabob the side where YOUNG RAPID is, Miss VORTEX to the other side.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I,—ha! ha! I say, dad, if the Nabob was to see us now,—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Ha! ha! True;—but mind what you're about.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I'll be discovered in a situation that will surprize—a striking situation, and in some damn'd elegant attitude

sp.speaker: O Rap.
sp.p: Why don't you sinish the job?—why don't you?
sp.stage: (They look round the other way, and see Miss VORTEX; they both appear ashamed and dejected; YOUNG RAPID draws his legs from under him.).

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Gentlemen,—I and my daughter, Miss Vortex, have done ourselves the honour of waiting upon you, to—

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: But I beg we may not interrupt your amusement;—'tis uncommon whimsical!

sp.speaker: Y. Rup.
sp.p: Yes, ma'm, very whimsical,—I must keep moving (laughs). Ha! ha! You see, dad, I've won,—I've won,—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: He says he has won—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Oh! he has won, has he?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Yes, you know I've won; he! he! why don't you laugh?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Ha! he!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: You see, ma'm, the fact is,—I had torn my coat; so says I to my father, I'll bet my bays against your opera box that I mend it; and so —ha! ha! (to OLD RAPID) Laugh again.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I can't,—indeed I can't.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: And so I—I won—upon my soul I was doing it very well.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: No, you were not,—you were doing it a shame to be seen.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Hush!—Ah, father, you don't like to lose.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, now this very extraordinary frolic is over—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Yes, sir,—it is quite over,— (aside) thank Heaven!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Suppose we adjourn to Bangalore-Hall?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Sir, I'll go with you directly with all the pleasure in life

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: I believe my curriele is the first carriage.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Dear me!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: My daughter seems to please you, sir.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: What a shape!

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Oh, sir, you're uncommon polite!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: He's remarkably gallant, ma'am.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: What elegance!—what fashion!—upon the whole, it's the best made little spencer I've seen for some time.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Oh, the devil!—The fact is, ma'am, my father is the most particular man on earth about dress —the beau of his time—Beau Rapid—You know, father, they always call'd you Bean Rapid.—I dare say he's had more suits of clothes in his house than any man in England.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: An uncommon expensive whim!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I don't think his fortune has suffer'd by it.
Shall I have the honour of driving you?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Oh, madam, I can't think of giving you so much trouble as to drive me.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: My dear sir,—I shall be uncommon happy!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Oh, madam!
sp.stage: (simpers and titters to his son, then takes Miss VORTEX'S hand, and trots off.)

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: We'll follow.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: If you please;—not that I particularly like to follow.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I suppose, sir, now summer approaches, London begins to fill for the winter.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Any thing new in high life?—what is the present rage with ladies of fashion?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Why, sir, as to the ladies;— (aside) What shall I say?—Oh, the ladies, sir—why, heaven bless them, sir! they—they keep moving;—but, to confess the truth sir,—my fashionable education has been very much neglected.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: That's a pity.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Very great pity, sir.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Suppose I become your preceptor.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: If you wou'd be so kind—I wou'd treasure any little short rule.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Why there is a short rule necessary for every man of fashion to attend to.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Never to reflect.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Never reflect!—what push on—keep moving?—My dear sir—that's my way—suits me exactly.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Then you must be known.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: To be sure;—I'll give away thousands in charities.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Charities!—you would be forgot in a week.—To be known, you must be mischievous; —malice has a much better memory than gratitude; —and then you must be gallant.—Are there no pretty gills you should like to be well with, eh?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: A very extensive assortment, sir.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: And perhaps there may be a married woman you would like to intrigue with.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: A very large quantity.—Oh, how I long to begin!—Are you married, sir?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Why, no!

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: The carriage is ready.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: So am I; come, sir,—four horses, I hope.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That's a great pity. Pray, sir, will you have the goodness to tell your coachman to drive like the devil?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Sir, to oblige you.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Sir, I'll be very much oblig'd to you.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Your clothes are come, sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That's lucky.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Then I'll wait for you.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Wait for me! nobody needs wait for me—I'll be with you in a crack—Do you push on —I'll keep moving—I'll take care nobody waits for me.

div3.head: SCENE II.—
div3.stage: A Room in the Nabob's House.
Enter OATLAND dejected, FRANK and JESSY leading him.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Be comforted, Father,

sp.speaker: Oat.
sp.p: To see thee brought to service! (sighs)— I've done this:—I that should have—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Never mind—we be young and healthy, and don't heed it—do us, Jessy?

sp.speaker: Oat.
sp.p: To be asham'd to look my own children in the face!—I, who ought to have been the fore-horse of the team, to be pull'd along through life by this young tender thing!

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Don't despond, Father—Sir Hubert will see your contrition, and restore you to his favour.

sp.speaker: Oat.
sp.p: When the hen sees the hawk ready to pounce, she gathers her young ones under her wing—when misfortune hovers over my sweet chicken here, I leave her to shift for herself.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Come, no more of this.

sp.speaker: Oat.
sp.p: Even the savage hawk takes care of its nestlings —what then am I?—Children, do you hate me?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Hate thee! pugh, Feyther, dan't thee talk so—good bye to thee—cheer up—Thee has long been a Feyther to me, now its my turn, and I'll be a Feyther to thee.

sp.speaker: Oat.
sp.p: I cannot speak—take care of my girl, Frank.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Care of her! though she be a sarvant, let me catch any body striking her, that's all.— Well, Jessy, we mun not be sheam'd—I know poverty be no sin, because parson said so last Sunday. —Talk of that—I do hear that your sweetheart, Mr. Rapid, be worth such a desperate sight of money as never was!

sp.speaker: Jessy
sp.p: If his fortunes are so prosperous, brother, he is exalted above my hopes—if his heart be mercenary, he is sunk below my wishes— Heigh ho! yet he might have sent to know if I were well, he might—no matter!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: He be coming to Neabob's here, on a visitation.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Ah! coming here!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ees—and Mr. Bronze do say while he be here I am to be his sarving man.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: You his servant!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Don't thee cry, Jessy!

sp.speaker: Jessy
sp.p:
I won't; it was weak, it was wrong.—Frank, be sure you conceal
from Mr. Rapid who you are—I have reasons for it.—Edward here!—when we meet it will be a hard trial. Yet why should I dread it?—let perfidy and pride shrink abash'd, virtuous integrity will support me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: That's right, Jessy, shew a proper spirit —Ecod, if he were to pull out his purse and to offer to make thee a present of five guineas, dan't thee take it.— (JESSY smiles dejectedly.)—Here be thy new mistress.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Leave me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Dost thou hear? Dom it, dan't thee take it!

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Oh! my new attendant, I suppose!— What's your name, child?

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Jessy Oatland, Madam.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Well, Oatland, (taking out her gloss,) look at me.—Umph—not at all contemptible.— That's a charming nosegay— (JESSY presents it)— all exotics, I declare.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: No, madam, neglected wild flowers—I took them from their bed of weeds, bestowed care on their culture, and, by transplanting them to a more genial soil, they have flourished with luxuriant strength and beauty.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: A pretty amusement.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: And it seems, madam, to convey this lesson —Not to despise the lowly mind, but rather with fostering hand, to draw it from its chill obscurity, that, like these humble flowers, it might grow rich in worth and native energy.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Oh! (aside),—mind—energy!— What's the matter with the poor girl, I wonder! uncommon odd!—I hear, Oatland, you are reduced in your circumstances.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Yes, madam.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: That's very lucky, because it will make you humble, child!—Well, and what are your qualifications?

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Cheerful industry, madam. I can read to you, write for you, or converse—

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Converse with me! I dare say you can.—No, thank you, child—instead of my listening to your voice, you will be polite enough to be as silent as convenient, and do me the honour of listening to mine.—Oh! here comes Mr. Rapid.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Ah! (in great agitation); May I retire madam?

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Yes; I shall follow to dress.—No, stay —Yes, you may go.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Oh, thank you! thank you, dear madam!

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: That poor girl appears to me rather crazy.

div3.stage: Enter OLD and YOUNG RAPID, and VORTEX.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Welcome to Bangalore Hall, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Charming house! plenty of room.—

div3.stage: (Runs about and looks at every thing.)

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: A very spacious apartment, indeed.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Yes, sir; but I declare I forgot the dimensions of this room.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Sir, if you please, I'll measure it—my cane is exactly a yard, good honest measure—'tis handy—and that mark is the half yard, and—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.stage: (Overhears, and snatches the cane from him.)
sp.p: Confound it! The pictures, father—look at the pictures (pointing with the cane); did you ever see such charming—

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Do you like pictures?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Exceedingly, ma'am; but I should like them a great deal better if they just moved a little.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Ha! ha! I must retire to dress—till dinner, gentlemen, adieu.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Zounds! you'll ruin every thing!—Can't you keep the taylor under.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Your son seems rather impatient.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Very, sir—always was.—I remember a certain Duke—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: That's right, lay the seene high,—push the Duke—push him as far as he'll go.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I will, I will. I remember a certain Duke used to say, Mr. Rapid, your son is as sharp as a needle.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: At it again!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: As a needle—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Is true to the pole, As a needle is true to the pole, says the Duke; so will your son, says the Duke, be to every thing spirited and fashionable, says the Duke.—Am I always to be tortur'd with your infernal needles?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Now to sound them.—I hear, gentlemen, your business in this part of the country is with Sir Hubert Stanley, respecting some money transactions.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: 'Tis a secret, sir.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh! no—the Baronet avows his wish to sell-his estate.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Oh! that alters the case.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I think it would be a desirable purchase for you—I should be happy in such neighbours— and if you should want forty or fifty thousand, ready money, I'll supply it with pleasure.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, how kind!—If my son wishes to purchase, I would rather leave it entirely to him.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: And I would rather leave it entirely to you.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Very well, I'll propose for it.— (aside). This will cut Sir Hubert to the soul.—There is a very desirable borough interest—then you could sit in Parliament.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I in Parliament? ha! ha!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: No; that would be a botch.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: No, no, I was once in the gallery— cramm'd in—no moving—expected to hear the great guns—up got a little fellow, nobody knew who, gave us a three hours' speech—I got dev'lish fidgetty—the House called for the question, I join'd the cry—"The question, the question," says I.—A Member spied me—clear'd the gallery —got hustl'd by my brother spectators—obliged to scud—Oh! it would never do for me.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: But you must learn patience.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Then make me a Speaker—if that wou'dn't teach me patience, nothing would.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Do you dislike, sir, Parliamentary eloquence?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Sir, I never heard one of your real downright parliament speeches in my life—never

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: By your yawning I shou'd think you had heard a great many.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh, how lucky!—at last I shall get my dear speech spoken.—Sir, I am a Member, and I mean to—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Keep moving.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Why, I mean to speak, I assure you; and—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Push on, then.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: What, speak my speech?—That I will—I'll speak it.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Oh, the devil!—Don't yawn so—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I never get a comfortable nap, never!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: You have a devilish good chance now— Confound all speeches.—Oh!—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Pray be seated— (they sit on each side VORTEX).—Now we'll suppole that the chair—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Suppose it a chair! why it is a chair, an't it?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Pshaw! I mean—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: He knows what you mean—'tis his humour.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh, he's witty!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Oh, remarkably brilliant indeed!—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: What, you are a wit, sir!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: A what? Yes, I am—I am a wit.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Well, now I'll begin.—Oh, what a delicious moment!—The House when they approve cry, "Hear him! hear him!"—I only give you a hint in case any thing should strike—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Push on.—I can never stand it—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Now I shall charm them— (addresses the chair) —"Sir, Had I met your eye at an earlier hour, I should not have blink'd the present question —but having caught what has fallen from the other side, I shall scout the idea of going over the usual ground."—What! no applause yet? (aside —During this OLD RAPID has fallen asleep, and YOUNG RAPID, after shewing great fretfulness and impatience, runs to the back scene, throws up the window and looks out)—"But I shall proceed, and, I trust without interruption"—
sp.stage: (turns round and sees OLD RAPID asleep).

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Upon my soul, this is—What do you mean, sir?—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: What's the matter?—Hear him! hear him!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Pray, sir, don't blush— (sees YOUNG RAPID at the window)—What the devil!—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Hear him! hear him!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: By the soul of Cicero, 'tis too much.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Oh, Neddy, tor shame of yourself to fall asleep!—I mean to look out of the window —I am very sorry, sir, any thing should go across the grain.—I say, Ned, smooth him down!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I will—What the devil shall I say? —The fact is, sir, I heard a cry of fire—upon —the—the—water, and—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Well, well—But do you wish to hear the end of my speech?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Upon my honour, I do.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Then we'll only suppose this little interruption a message from the Lords, or something of that sort.—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Where did I leave off?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Oh! I recollect; at—"I therefore briefly conclude with moving an adjournment"—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Nonsense! no such thing— (putting him down in the chair.)—Oh! I remember! "I shall therefore proceed, and, I trust, without interruption.—"

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Dinner's on the table, sir.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Get out of the room, you villain!— "Without interruption—"

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I say, sir—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Hear him! hear him!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Dinner is waiting.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap
sp.p: Dinner waiting!— Come along, sir.

sp.speaker: Vortex
sp.p: Never mind the dinner.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: But I like it smoking.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: So do I—Be it ever so little, let me have it hot.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Won't you hear my speech?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: To be sure we will—but now to dinner. —Come, we'll move together—Capital speech! —Push on, sir—Come along, dad—Push him on, dad.

div3.head: SCENE III.—
div3.stage: Enter Sir HUBERT, leaning on CHARLES STANLEY.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Take comfort, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Where shall I find it, boy?—To live on my estate, is ruin—to part with it, death.—My heart is twin'd round it.—I've been the patriarch of my tribe—the scourge of the aggressor—the protector of the injur'd!—Can I forego these dignities? —my old grey-headed servants, too, whose only remaining hope is to lay their bones near their lov'd master, how shall I part with them?—I prate, boy, but 'tis the privilege of these white hairs.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Oh! say on, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p:
All! all is dear to me!—these warlike trophies of my ancestors!—Charles, thou see'st that goodly oak, 'twas planted at my birth— Would'st thou think it? In the late hurricane, when the tempest humbled with the dust the proudest of the forest, it bravely met the driving blast—my people with shouts of joy, hail'd the auspicious omen, and augur'd from it prosperity to me and
mine—Fondly I believ'd it—fondly I thought it. Fie! fie! I doat—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: My father, I doubt not but they augur'd truly. I must to the active world. Why should I fear that the virtue and independence you have inspir'd—

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Ah, boy! but while licentiousness and party zeal command the choicest gifts of fortune, virtue and genius must be content with their leavings.

div3.stage: Enter Servant—delivers a letter to Sir HUBERT, who reads it with great agitation.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Ah! what is it shakes you, sir?—That letter!

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Nothing, my dear boy!—'tis infirmity! —I shall soon be better.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Excuse me, dear Sir (takes the letter and reads).Mr. Vortex, at the request of Mr. Rapid, informs Sir Hubert Stanley, it is inconvement for him to advance more money on mortgage.
