Mr. Vortex laments Sir Hubert's pecuniary embarrassments—damnation!— to relieve which, he will purchase the castle and estate.—Sooner shall its massy ruins crumble me to dust.—Don't despond, my father:—bear up!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Oh Sir!—At Neabob's table they've een so abusing your father!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Ah?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And I've been sighting—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Hush!

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: What's his business?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Oh, sir! (concealing his agitation)—My friend Frank consults me on a love assair; and I must not betray his considence.—In his hurry he sell.—Wasn't it so

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ees, fur, ees.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: You are not hurt, young man?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No, fur.—Thank heaven! my head be a pure hard one.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Within!— (Enter two Servants) Attend my Father.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: My boy, don't stay from me long.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Now, good Frank, ease my tortur'd mind.—What of my father?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, your honour, Mr. Bronze came laughing out of dining-room, and says, "Daame, how the old Baronet has been roasted." So, fur, I not knowing what they could mean by roasting a Christian, axed. "Why," says he, grinning. "they voted, that it was a pity the dignity of the bloody hand interfer'd, or the old beggar might set up a shop."

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: The old beggar might set up a shop.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Unmanner'd, cowardly babblers.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And that you, fur, would make a dapper 'prentice.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I heed not that.—But, when I forgive a father's wrongs—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: So says I, Domme, if young 'squire had been among them, he would have knocked all their heads together. Now wouldn't you, fur, have knock'd their heads together? Then they all laugh'd at me: which somehow made all the blood in my body come into my knuckles. So says I, "Mr. Bronze, suppose a case—suppose me young 'squire Stanley—now, say that again about his honour'd father."—So he did; and I lent him such a drive o'the feace—and I was knocking all their heads together pretty tightish—till the cook laid me flat wi' the poker: then they all fell upon me; and when I could sight no longer, I fell a crying, and run to tell your honour.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Thanks, my affectionate lad!—Return to the Nabob's to-day.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I be sartain I shall never do any good there.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: To morrow you shall live with me. I shall dismiss all my servants—my circumstances require it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What! all but me!—What! I do all the work?—Lord, Lord, how glad I be, fur, you can't afford to keep any body but I.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Good Frank, farewell—Hold—here

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Nay, prayee, fur, dan't you beheave unkind to me—I be a poor lad, that do worship and love you—not a spy for the lucre of gain—pray use me kindly, and don't gi' me a farding.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Frank, I beg your pardon—Farewell!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Lord, how glad I be he can only afford to keep I.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Insult my father!—unmanly villain!— who'er thou art, thy life shall answer it!

div3.head: SCENE I.—
div3.stage: Enter VORTEX, in great terror, reading a letter.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Dear me!—here's a terrible affair! (reads)Give me up the author of the slander on my father that was myself—I never can find in my heart to give myself up— or personally answer the consequences—CHARLES STANLEY.—Oh dear! since I sind my words are taken down, I must be more parliamentary in my language—What shall I do?—I can't sight—my poor head won't bear it —it might be the death of me.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Huzza, my fine fellows! Bravo!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p:
Eh! egad, a fine thought—Young Rapid is loaded muzzel high with Champaigne— I'll tell him he said the words, and make him own them. I've persuaded him into a marriage with
my daughter; after that, the devil's in't if I can't persuade him into a duel.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Here I am, tip-top spirits—ripe for any thing.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: How did you like my Champaigne?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Oh! suits me exactly; a man is such a damn'd long while getting tipsy with other wine —Champaigne fettles the business directly—it has made me—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Lively, I see.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Lively—it has made me like a skyrocket. Well, how did I behave?—Quite easy, wasn't I?—Push'd on—at every thing—barr'd prosing.—Jolly dogs within—the fat parson's a fine fellow—kept the bottle moving—said a nice short grace.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Well, and did you lose at play the five hundred pounds I let you?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: As easy as could be.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: That was lucky.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Very—particularly for those who won it.—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Well, now you'll do.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Huzza! I'm a finish'd man

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: You only want a quarrel to make you—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: A what?—A quarrel—Damme, I'll settle that in two minutes

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Stop.—You need not go out of the room for that.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: What! will you quarrel with me, eh? —With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Me! Oh no!—I say I could get you such same—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: How, my dear fellow?—Dash on.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Why, at dinner you reflected on the Baronet.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: No, it was you.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: No, not I.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Yes, it was you.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Well, it might be I; but I don't say it was—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I. do.—Push on.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Young Stanley has demanded the author.— Now, if you were to own the words—how the news-papers would teem with—"The elegant Charles Stanley was called out by the dashing: Young Rapid about some trifle"—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Bravo!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Any thing does for a duel now a-days— the length of a dancer's great toe—an election leg of mutton and trimmings.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Say no more—I'll do it. By heavens, no man of fashion will be more infamous—I mean more famous.—I'll go write to him directly.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: First take another bottle of Champaigne. You can't think what a free dashing stile it will give you.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I will (going—returns.) No, I can't take up this quarrel.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh dear!—Why not?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Because I'm sure I'm depriving you of a pleasure.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh, don't mind me! I give it you, to shew my regard for you.—Indeed, I've had so much fighting in my time, that with me it really ceases to be a pleasure—the sweetest things will cloy—so the quarrel's your's—I wash my hands of it.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: You're a damn'd good hearted, generous fellow!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Then you'll return triumphant, and marry my daughter.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: To be sure—keep moving (going). I hope he'll fight directly.—Like a sailor, I hate a calm, particularly when an enemy's in fight.— Hold—what must we sight with? I can fence.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: You have no objection to pistols and bullets?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I like bullets—they come so quick. But I must push on—the other bottle, and then— I'm a first-rats fellow.—Champaigne for ever!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: You shall have my pistols—hey've never been used. (Enter Miss VORTEX.) Here's policy. "Crown me, shadow me, wich laurels."—Oh my dear, I've atchiev'd two such difficult points!

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: How, my dear Nabob?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: In the first place, I've persuaded Young Rapid to marry you.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Was that so difficult?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: No, no, certainly. But the next will delight you.—Rapid is going to have an affair of honour with Young Stanley.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: A duel! and about me!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Yes.— (aside) I may as well tell her so.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Charming!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Now an't I a kind father, to set two young men fighting about you?

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Ah! that is, indeed, acting like a parent!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Egad, I must look after Rapid, though.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: But how did you manage it?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: By policy, to be sure: for, as I observe in my speech—"Policy is—"

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: And a very good observation it is.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: How do you know, till you hear it?— "Policy—"

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: But pray go to Mr. Rapid

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: "Policy—"

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Nay, I must insist— (Exit VORTEX.) Oh delightful!—Oatland!
I'm in such uncommon spirits, Oatland!

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: May I inquire the cause, madam?

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Certainly. A duel is going to be fought about me.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: A duel! Horrible thought!

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Sensibility, I now! Too comic, a vast deal! Ha! ha! cottage pathos must proceed from a source unknown to me, I'm sure!

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: It proceeds, madam, from the heart.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Umph!—Let me have no more of it

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: I beg your pardon—I forgot the extent of a servant's duty.—I forgot that servants have no right to feel pleasure or pain, but as their employers please; and that suppressing the sensibilities of Nature is consider'd in their wages

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: No doubt of it.—That's so very sensibly observ'd, that I'll forgive you, Oatland.— The pride of young Stanley will be so humbled—

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Is the safety of that noble youth implicated?

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: What!—A lover, I suppose—came to the farm, I warrant—attended Miss Jessy in the dairy—ruffled the cream with his sighs—talked of Arcadia, and sipped butter-milk.—Ha! ha! I should not wonder, after what I have seen of his taste—Yes, he is implicated—I dare say Mr. Rapid will—

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Heavens! Is Edward—
sp.stage: (catching hold of a chair for support).

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Edward!

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: I mean, madam, (trembling and curtesying,) is Mr. Rapid's life involv'd?

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Upon my honour, you seem to have an uncommon sensibility for all mankind!—Do you mean to sit down in my presence?

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: No, madam! (sinks down in the chair). Oh, Edward, unkind as thou art, how gladly would I resign my life, to save thee!

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: In tears, Jessy?—Sweet girl, tell me—

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Oh, madam! the most dreadful event is about to take place. Mr. Stanley is engaged in a duel with—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Forbid it, Heaven.—Let us fly to his Father:—he may prevent it.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Alas, madam! I fear he regards not his Father's injunctions.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Not regard his Father:—who, child?

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Mr. Rapid, madam!

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Mr. Rapid?

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Is it so, sweet Jessy?—But has he deserv'd thy love?—Is he not unkind?

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Oh! true, madam!—But is not his life in danger?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: We will not lose a moment.—Let us seek Sir Hubert.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: I'm very faint.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: I'll support thee; for in addition to the oppression of our common grief, thou, sweet girl, must bear the agonizing weight of disappointed love. —Come, rest on my arm.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Oh, such kindness!—I cannot speak— but indeed my heart feels it.

div3.head: SCENE II.—
div3.stage: Enter YOUNG RAPID, followed by FRANK, who carries Pistols, a Sword, and Champaigne.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Got the pistols, eh?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Here they be (lays them down).—Your Feather were axing for you, fur.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: My father!—Should any thing happen —when I reflect—Reflect—Zounds, that won't do. Some Champaigne (singing) "If a man can then die much bolder with brandy" (drinks). I'll write to him, however;—a few words on a scrap of paper may cheer him (takes a letter out of his pocket, and is about to tear a piece of it off). What! (reads) "Dear Edward, your faithful Jessy Oatland" (strikes his head)—Jessy Oatland!—What a scoundrel I am! (kisses the letter).—Oh, Jessy, what an infernal pain at my heart!—More Champaigne!

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: A letter, sir, from Young Stanley.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Then the die is cast.— (Reads) "You are a scoundrel—meet me immediately, or,"—Um, um, a decisive short letter enough. Damn this pain.—Quick! my pistols! Take them to Stanley Park: there wait for me.—Oh! Jessy!

div3.stage: Enter OLD RAPID at the back scene.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ecod, he'll kill thee.—I'll lay half acrown 'Squire Stanley hits thee the first shot.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Pistols—kill— Stanley!—Ned, tell me—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: My father here.—Oh, fir, nothing.—Come, drink.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Look at me.—Ah, that agitation!— Tell me the cause!—A parent commands you.— Your old doating father intreats it!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I must deceive him.—Sir, l've receiv'd an insult that no gentleman of fashion can submit to.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Gentleman of fashion!—Need a man resent it?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Read that letter, and judge.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Lack a day! consider you're only a taylor's son.— (Reads) "You're a scoundrel."— That's a hard word.—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Wou'd you have me submit to be call'd scoundrel?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: No, I wou'dn't— (with tears).—Yes, I wou'd.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Sir, you don't feel like a man.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I'm sure I feel like a father!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Read on, sir.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: "And unless" (wipes the tears away,) "unless"—I can't—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: "And unless you immediately give me the satisfaction of a gentleman, expect the chastisement due to a coward."

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Chastisement!—chastisement!— Coward! (with irritation). We are flesh and blood, Ned.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Wou'd you see me spurn'd?—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.stage: (emphatically, and running into his Son's arms.)
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Pray leave me, sir.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p:
Where shall I go?—What shall I do? —What will become of me? Oh, boy, try to
avoid it.—Remember your old father,—remember his life hangs on your's. But, Ned—don't forget you're a man!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Pray leave me, sir.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I will.—Farewell, my dear boy, 'twill break my old heart.—But remember you're a man, Ned.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: So, I'm proceeding full tilt to murder;—have planted a dagger in a kind father's heart—But here goes— (fills wine—throws away the bottle and glass)—Its power is gone. Oh— this infernal pain! Could I with honour avoid? —but (looking at the letter)—Chastisement! Coward! —Damnation! I must push on. Fool! Dolt! Villain that I am!

div3.head: SCENE III.—

stage.hi: A retired place in Stanley Park.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: What can it mean?—Charles parted from me in an agony the ingenuousness of his nature had not art to conceal;—he grasp'd my hand,— bade me farewell, as if it were for ever,—then broke away—leaving me a prey to wild conjecture and despait;—soon shall I be at peace.—infirmity, when goaded on by sorrow, presses to the goal of life with double speed—Surely thro' that laurel grove, I see two female figures glide along; my eyes are not of the best, and the sorrow I have felt for my dear boy has not strengthened them; —they approach—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Pardon, Sir Hubert, this intrusion!— My name, Sir, is Ellen Vortex.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Madam, I welcome you as my daughter.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Oh, sir!—the urgency of the moment will not allow me to thank such goodness as I ought! —your son, sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Ah! What of him?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p:
I saw him pass along, he sled from my
outstretch'd arms,—he was deaf to my cries;—e'en now he's engaged in a duel.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Ha! (draws his sword and is running out, staggers, drops his sword.—ELLEN and JESSY support him) My functions are suspended!—Oh nature! dost thou desert me at this moment?—Who is the villain that has caused it?

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Ah, my poor Edward!

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Oh that I could rush before my child, and receive the fatal ball in this old broken heart!— Perhaps—dreadful thought!—e'en now the deadly tube is levelled at his manly breast. (The report of a pistol is heard—ELLEN sinks into his arms.) Bear up, I cannot support thee. (Another pistol is discharged)—Horrible suspense!—what a death-like silence!

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Death!—Oh, my ador'd Charles!

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Ah, my poor Edward!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Huzza! huzza! (enters) Huzza!—He's safe—he's safe.—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Who?—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: 'Squire Charles,—'Squire Charles,— Huzza!

div3.stage: (Exit.—Sir HUBERT folds his hands on his breast in silent gratitude.)

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Ah, my poor Edward!

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Your son is safe;—heard you the words?

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: They have shot life thro' me.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Jessy! rejoice with me— (Seeing her dejected) Wretch that I am, to forget thy sorrows! —Take comfort, sweet girl!—perhaps—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Tol de rol lol—Safe and sound—safe and found—tol de rol lol.—

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: My boy Neddy,—my darling Neddy, safe and sound,—tol de rol lol.
sp.stage: (Sees Sir HUBERT, and bows respectfully. JESSY and ELLEN talk apart.)

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: So, Mr. Rapid!—How happened this, sir?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p:
Really, Sir Hubert, I don't understand the cut of it; all I can say is, your son's behaviour
was—oh—supersine;—when they had fired their pistols they drew out their swords, and your son disarm'd Neddy, and then he generously gave him his sword again, which was extremely genteel,— for it was a brand new silver-hilted sword, and, I suppose by the laws of honour he might have kept it.—

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Mr. Rapid, why did you break your appointment?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Mr. Vortex, sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Mr. Vortex.—I fear your son has selected an imprudent preceptor.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Chose a bad pattern you think, sir?— I am afraid he has—

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Will you, sir, favour me with a few minutes conversation?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: You know, Sir Hubert, I'm your faithful servant to command.—
Come, let us to our hero. Will you, fair creature, condescend to be a crutch to an old man? (takes ELLEN'S arm.) I shall expect you, sir.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Jessy!

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: I follow, madam. (Exeunt Sir HUBERT and ELLEN.) Do I address the father of Mr. Rapid?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: You do, pretty one!

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: I beg your pardon; but are you sure your son's life is safe —quite safe?—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Yes.—A very charming girl, I declare! —I'm very much obliged to you for taking notice of my Neddy!—Poor fellow!—nobody seem'd to care what became of him.—I'm very much oblig'd.—A sweet pretty-spoken creature as ever I saw! But I must away to the Nabob's, or I shall be too late for the wedding.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Wedding! whose, sir?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Whose! why, my boy Neddy's with Miss Vortex, to be sure!

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Married! Edward married! 'Tis too much—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Eh! what! speak—tell me!

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Oh, Edward! is this the return for my love? have I merited this cruel desertion?

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Desertion!—What!—has the rascal—I shall choak myself—Has he behaved ill to so sweet a creature? Your tears tell me so—I'll kill him.—He's my own son, and I have a right to do it—Your name, your name! pretty soul!

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Jessy Oatland.—The indiscretion of my father has made me a servant.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: And the discretion of his father has made him a gentleman—But I'll make the rascal know you are not humbled by your Father's conduct, nor is he exalted by his, a villain!—Can he hope to be call'd a man of honour for opposing his head to a pistol, while himself levels the shaft of anguish at an innocent woman's heart?—But I'll kill him, that's one comfort.—Come with me, sweet one!

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Sir, I must attend my mistress—I am servant to his bride—

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I shall go mad!—Don't cry—If he, by marriage, won't make you my daughter— I, by adoption, will.—Good bye, sweet Jessy! —Oh, the rascal!—Cheer up?—the scoundrel! —Pretty creature!—The dog!—What a shape!—I'll kill him!

div3.head: SCENE I.—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Dispatch! why don't you dispatch?

sp.speaker: H. D.
sp.p: Done in a moment, sir, pray keep your head still.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Oh, Jessy Oatland!— S'death—have not you done?

sp.speaker: H. D.
sp.p: Sit down, sir, done in a moment.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Well, well; I'm as patient as— (Sits —Enter FRANK at the door, RAPID jumps up and runs to him).—Well!—Speak—quick!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sur—I—that is—she—no, I went—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: You tedious blockhead—Is she gone? Is Jessy gone?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ees, sur.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What! left her Father's!—Where is she?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I don't know—that is, I won't tell—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What must she think me? What I am— a rascal.

sp.speaker: H. D.
sp.p: Sit down, sir;—done in a moment.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I am as calm as—
What do you want?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, my master and Miss Vortex wait for you.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Aye, to fulfil that infernal marriage promise.—Oh, Jessy! (to FRANK) What are you at?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sur, I were only twiddleing about my thumbs.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: You are always twiddling about your thumbs. What shall I do? Go to them.—No, I'll write.—I want to write.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Oh, you do?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: I tell you I want to write.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I'm sure I don't hinder you.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! then don't stand there.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: It be all the same to me where I stand—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Thickhead, bring pen and ink.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why did you not tell I so?

div3.stage: Exit, and returns with pens and ink.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Oh, this infernal pain!—A candle to seal a letter (Exit. FRANK, and returns with a candle.) —Zounds! it is not lighted!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You didn't tell I to light it.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Was ever man plague'd with such a hollow-headed ninny-hammer.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: May be that be better than a hollow-hearted one!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My master has sent you those parchments to peruse.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: I wouldn't read them for his estate.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: He will wait on you sir, directly.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Begone all of you!—Stop (to FRANK.) Give me my coat! (FRANK helps him on with one arm.)—Bring the glass!— (FRANK leaves him so, and brings down a dressing glass.)—Leave me, dunderhead!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Bravo, my sine fellow! you fought nobly!—I say, who sir'd first?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Never mind, that's past!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Well, now I must entrust you with a little secret—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: I have no objection to a little secret.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: In the first place, then, I'll read this paper.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: No; I'll read it—I shall read it much quicker. Reads.—"Receiv'd of Mr. Vortex the sum of five thousand pounds, in consideration of which I assign over all my right and title to— hum, um, um—Signed, ELLEN VORTEX."— I understand—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Now you must know the father of my niece—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Jessy Oatland!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: No, her name is Ellen.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: I know it, I know it—I know it—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Her father died in India.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: With all your heart!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Zounds! keep moving, will you?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Yes, if you'll keep still.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Then be quick,

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Why I am quick, an't I?—Died in India, and left her to my care. All was in—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Confusion.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: You are right, all was in confusion. So I prevail'd on—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Jessy Oatland!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: No, no, Ellen—to sign that paper; since which, indeed her affairs have turn'd out pretty lucky. I purchas'd this estate with her fortune, which will be your's, my boy!—It was a very snug bargain.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What a horrible thing is the gift of speech!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Speech!—Did you say any thing about a speech? Ah! had you heard mine out.—Do you remember how it began?—"Had I met your eye at an earlier hour, I should"—
sp.stage: (During VORTEX's narration, RAPID, influenced by the most fretful impatience, has unconsciously bit, and torn to pieces, the paper given him by VORTEX.)

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: 'Sdeath and sire! is this a time for speeches! Is not your daughter waiting? —Is not?—Oh Jessy!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: True, another opportunity! But, oh! 'tis a pretty speech.—Well, now give me back the paper.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: The paper!

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: Yes, now you have thoroughly digested the contents of the paper, give it me again.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Oh! the—the—the paper

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Yes; that precious scrap that secures us a hundred thousand pounds, you dog!—Come, give it me.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: My dear fellow! you gave me no paper.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: But I did, though.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Yes, you certainly did; but then—you —you—did not—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: But I'll take my oath I did!—Come, give it me directly!—You— (sees the fragments on the ground). Eh! what!—No;—yes.—I'm undone, I'm ruin'd.—Oh, my head! I'm going, I'm going!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Upon my soul I'm very sorry, but—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: That infernal speech!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh! (looking at the scraps of paper)— Eh, but hold! when he marries my daughter he'll keep the secret for his own sake. Oh dear! I must lose no time.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: I'm very sorry; I'm sure if hearing your speech will be any compensation—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: No, no, not now—come with me, all the lawyers are waiting.—Oh, pray come!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: I'm coming, but you're always in such a hurry.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I'll send my daughter to him—I must push him. Pray come directly.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Upon my soul you'll break your neck, if you hurry so. Am I always to have this infernal pain? (goes up to the glass). Behold a high-finished rascal at full length.—Curse me, if I can look myself in the face.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: There he stands!—Now, heart, be firm.—Virtuous indignation support me! Sir, my mistress waits for you.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Don't plague me about your mistress. I'll come by and by.— (Turns round) Heaven and hell! Jessy Oatland!

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: My mistress, sir, waits for you.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Your mistress!—A servant! Jessy Oatland a servant!—A servant to—and I—Jessy! my life!—my soul!—will you forgive—?

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Wretch!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: I am.—I despise myself.—On my knees— only listen to me.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Mr. Rapid!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: How can you debase yourself—to—

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: How can you debase yourself—to—

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: How dare he debase me, madam, by offering to an honest heart the affections of a villain?

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Leave the room!

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Now, poor heart! having pass'd thy pride's probation, retire to a corner, and break with weeping.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Sir! what am I to understand?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: That I'm crazy.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Have I deserv'd insult?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Upon my soul, I don't mean to insult you —I ask your pardon—upon my knees

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You, fur!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Well, I'll forgive you if you'll come directly.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You be's a desperate villain! (RAPID going to strike.) Come, dan't you do that—it won't do.—Poor sister! if you had drawn a harrow across her heart, you could not have hurt her so.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Damn't—I know nothing of your sister! Who the devil is your sister? you—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why! Jessy Oatland!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What! your sister—the brother of Jessy my servant?—Damnation! why did not you tell me so? to raise my hand against the brother of Jessy?—I shall go mad!—Frank, will you forgive me? I love Jessy—by my soul I do!—And may heaven desert me, if—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Heyday!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Leave the room! [Exit FRANK] insult upon insult!—What satisfaction—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: I know what you want. Come along; I'll sight you directly.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Fight! Nonsense.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Then I'll ask your pardon.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: But what the devil's the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Why, don't you see I'm mad?—Stark flaring mad!

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: Mr. Rapid!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh! Lord, how fierce Stanley looks at me. Pray come, Mr. Rapid.— (To STANLEY) Sir, your most obedient!

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: That little fellow will break his neck to a certainty.

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: I have just seen a lovely girl that you have wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: I know I have; and I'll fight you again, if you like it.

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: Could the result benesit Jessy Oatland, I would accept your invitation.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: The fact is, I am the most unhappy—the —What do you charge for shooting a man? I'll give you a thousand to blow my brains out. I'm the most miserable dog—Pray, sir, will you tell me one thing?—Are you a man of fashion?

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: I trust I'm a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: That's pretty much the same thing—an't it, sir?

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: It ought to be.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Pray, sir, how did you become a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: Simply, by never committing an action that would not bear reflection.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Can I be a gentleman and an honest man?

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: Can you be a gentleman, and not an honest man?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: Pray, sir, have you always an infernal pain at your heart?

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: No! Huzza! Thank you!—By heaven I'll—Now don't hurry yourself.—If I don't, may I—

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: Ah! Mr. Rapid, how different are our situations! You, possessing the love of a most charming and fascinating girl, dash the cup of happiness away.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: May be not, my dear fellow!—Push on.

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: I, possessing the heart of my dear Ellen, am miserable: because on account of the narrowness of her fortune, she compels me to abandon her.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: What! The narrowness of her fortune compels—

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: Yes! I say—

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: No! Don't say it again. Don't despair, that's all

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: She has given a fatal paper.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: A paper!—Yes, I know, I know.

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.p: And I'm come to take leave of her.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.p: No, you are not!—I'll show you such a scene.—Nay, don't ask me any questions—follow me, that's all.—Wait at the door; and when I cry, Hem! come in. But don't be in such a hurry. By heavens, the pain in my side is better already! Huzza!—Come along! (Going, returns, and runs to the glass and nods.) How do you do? How do you do? What! you rascal! you can grin again, can you? Come along; but don't hurry; because, my dear fellow! 'tis impossible to do any thing well in a hurry. Come along! but, zounds! never hurry.

div3.head: SCENE II.—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: How bee'st thee now, Jessy?

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Better. Quite recover'd. What pass'd between you and Edward?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, at first, he were in a desperate passion; but when I told him I were thy brother, he were so humble, and did ax I; so to forgive un, that I could say no more to un. Dom it, I could not hit him, when he were down; and I've a notion his conscience was pegging him about pretty tightish. He swear'd he did love thee!

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Did he, Frank? Did he say he lov'd me?

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: What! torn the paper!—A hot headed—only wait till he's my husband—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Egad, I wish he would come, tho'—

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Oh! here he is.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: How my poor frame trembles!

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: I vow I feel uncommon discompos'd —Oatland! your arm, child!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Heavens, how interesting! the languor of those lovely eyes—

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Flattering creature!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: My senses are restor'd. Oh, will you pardon—will you again receive a heart full of love and adoration?—

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: What shall I do?—I must pardon him.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Edward! what shall I say?—your love has been too long my joy,—my pride, to be torn from my heart without many a bitter wound;— (Miss VORTEX with surprize and chagrin withdraws her arm from JESSY;)— but your late conduct has been—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Detestable?—But I'm pardon'd, your eyes tell me so. Thanks, my angel! (running to her and kneeling.) I'm so oppress'd with joy.— Ma'am, will you have the goodness to help me up?—

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Help you up!—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: He! he! he! Gi' me a buss, Jessy! he! he! thee be's a domn'd honest fellow! (shaking RAPID's hand.) I'll run and tell poor Feyther —Now I shall have a farm of my own! (capering and snapping his singers.)—Dong it, how I will work. He! he! he!

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: To be us'd so twice in one day!—it is not to be borne.—Nabob! won't you sight him?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: No, not I.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: Coward!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: You'd better be quiet, or I'll convince you I'm none, however.

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: He! he! I declare it is so uncommon ridiculous!—so comic!—He! he!—I'm quite faint with laughing.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Shall I assist you?

sp.speaker: Miss Vor.
sp.p: No! (resentsully.) I must retire, or I shall expire with laughing!—he! he!—Oh!—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Heaven! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Allow me to introduce Mrs. Rapid, madam.—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Sweet Jessy!—Sir, I thank you, for giving my heart a pleasurable sensation which I thought it had for ever taken leave of.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Bless your heart! perhaps I may tickle it up a little more.— (To VORTEX) Now, stand out of the way, will you?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: You're quite free and easy.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: My way.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: You forget 'tis my house.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: No, I don't;—you bought it with her money, you know—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Umh!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Mum, now for young Stanley's cue. (To ELLEN) 'Ppon my honour, ma'am, any man might be proud to—Hem—He doesn't hear me— Such beauty!—such a shape! such a—Hem—

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Zounds! he's here again (getting behind YOUNG RAPID). What does he want?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Shall I ask him?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Do.—I'll be very much oblig'd to you.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I will.—I'll manage

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh, thank you!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Once more, my Ellen! supported by indulgent parent's blessing on our union, I entreat—

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Oh Charles! shall I then return your father's goodness by destroying his hopes for ever? Shall I repay my Stanley's love by inslicting on him penury and sorrow? In pity, no more!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.—
sp.p: What may may be your business here, sir?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I came to take leave.—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Hush! (apart).—To inquire respecting that lady's fortune. We'll soon answer all that, won't we?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I say, sir—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: We grant it,—we grant Mr. Vortex has recover'd property to a considerable amount, but what signisies that? She assigned it for five thousand pounds!—You see how I'm going on

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh, thank you, my dear friend!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I've seen the paper; haven't I?—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: And I shou'd be satisfied—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: You wou'd be satisfied if you faw. it— Certainly—very proper—nothing in nature can be more reasonable; so, Nabob, shew him the paper, and settle the business at once (walks about, VORTEX following him.). Shew him the paper!—don't keep the gentleman waiting all day.—Shew him the paper. My dear fellow! what's the use of walking after me? Shew him the paper.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.stage: (taking advantage of the pauses in the foregoing speech.)
sp.p: I say, my dear friend, hush! Be quiet! I want to speak to you; you forget you destroyed it.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I destroyed it!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Hush!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: He says I destroyed it!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: I did not.—I'll take my oath I did not.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: And it is true.

sp.speaker: Charles and Ellen.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: True, upon my honour! He has no more hold on your estates, madam, than I have.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Will you now allow the humble Stanley to destroy the hopes of wealthy Ellen? Will you permit me to repay your love with penury and sorrow?

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: Oh, chide on! (raising him) Dear Stanley, my happiness is now complete.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p:
This is your house, ma'am. I give
you joy!—Sir, I give you joy!—Nabob, I give you joy!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Oh, my head! You villain!

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Don't talk about villainy,—it will make you worse. Sit down, my dear fellow!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: He's justly punished for the falsehood of the story he told.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I say, he's justly punished for the length of the story he told.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Mr. Rapid, in expressing my obligations, allow me to be—

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Not more than a minute, I entreat.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Be patient.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I won't.—Let me come at him.

div3.stage: Enter OLD RAPID and SIR HUBERT.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: Your blessing, sir!

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: What? Oh!
sp.stage: (falls down on his knees and embraces them both.)

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Mr. Rapid, by asserting your character as a man of honour, in rewarding the affections of this amiable woman, you command my praise; for bestowing happiness on my dear Charles, receive an old man's blessing.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Approbation from Sir Hubert Stanley is praise indeed.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Dam'me, there's the son of a taylor for you!

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: What, a taylor?

sp.speaker: O. Rat.
sp.p: Yes; and let me tell you, that one guinea honestly gotten by blood drawn from the singer, is sweeter than a million obtained by blood drawn from the heart!—So, take that.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Well, Nabob, how do you feel?

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p:
Egad, 'tis very odd;—but I declare I feel light and comfortable since Ellen has got her
estate, and I somehow breathe more free. I've a notion the last line of my speech is true.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Come, I'll hear the last line.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Why, that the first step towards securing the esteem of others, is to secure your own.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: Stick to the last line.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: And, dear uncle, take Sir Hubert Stanley for your physician. Follow his prescription of justice and benevolence, and my life on it, you will soon thank me for my recommendation.

sp.speaker: Vortex.
sp.p: Well, to shew the sincerity of my intentions, allow, me, Ellen, to present you these parchments, the title deeds of this estate.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: I say, Ned, what nice measures they would make!

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p: And, sir, allow me to shew you the true value of riches— (giving parchments. to STANLEY)— Convert them into happiness.

sp.speaker: O. Rap.
sp.p: Well, I've only one observation to make.

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I hope it is a snort one.

sp.speaker: Jessy.
sp.p: What, impatient again?

sp.speaker: Y. Rap.
sp.p: I am; and if I err
sp.l: 'Tis you, my gen'rous Patrons, are the cause,
My heart's impatient for your kind applause.

div1.head: EPILOGUE,
div1.byline: WRITTEN BY M. P. ANDREWS, ESQ. M. P. SPOKEN BY MRS. MATTOCKS.

lg.l: SHAKESPEARE, a shrewd old quiz, in his dull age,
Said, very gravely, "All the world's a stage."
But if the Poet on our times could drop,
He'd rather own that "all the world's a shop."
"And what's the trade?" exclaim the critic railers
Why, "Men and women all are merely taylors."
Nay, frown not, Beaux; and Ladies, do not pout
You've all your cuttings in and cuttings out.
And, first, Miss Hoyden, just escap'd from school
Slighting mamma, and all domestic rule;
If she on fashion's road should chance to trip,
What says the world? why, "Miss has made a slip.
And if, a falling character to save,
She weds with age just tott'ring o'er the grave,
The sportive world will still enjoy the joke,
And spouse, at home, at once is made a cloke.
The Politician too, who when in place,
Views public measures with a smiling sace,
Croaks, when he's out, a discontented note,—
Sure he's a taylor—he has turn'd his coat.
Oft have I measur'd you when closely sitting,
To see what twist, what shape, what air was sitting.
Once more I'll try, if you'll make no resistance;
Mine's a quick eye, and measures at a distance.
Great Mr. Alderman—your worship—sir,
If you can stomach it, you need not stir,
Room you require, for turtle and for haunch,
'Tis done—two yards three quartersround the paunch.
Slim sir, hold up your arm—Oh, you're a Poet,
You want a coat, indeed—your elbows show it.
Don't tremble, man; there's now no cause for fears,
Though oft you shirk the Gemmen of the sheers;
Genius stands still, when taylors interpose,
'Tis like a watch—it ticks—and then it goes.
The needle dropt, the warlike sword I draw,
or oft our sex must yield to martial law;
ady Hubbuffet came to me last night,
"Oh, my dear ma'am, I'm in such a fright:
"They've drawn me for a man; and, what is worse,
"I am to soldier it, and mount a horse:
"Must wear the breeches." Says I, "Don't deplore
"What in your husband's life you always wore;
"But that your La'ship's heart may cease from throbbing,
"Let your fat Coachman mount upon fat Dobbin;
"And for the good old pair I'll boldly say,
"Nor man, nor horse, will ever run away."
"Run!"—"Arrah, who is that dare fear betray?"
Cries patriot Paddy, hot from Bantry-Bay.)
"The Frenchmen came expecting us to meet 'em,
"And sure we all were ready there to greet 'em,
"With piping hot potatoes made of lead,
"And powder that would serve instead of bread;
"And, by my soul, such dainty fine fat frogs,
"With warm dry lodging for them in the bogs."
"They came, alas!" cried I, of terror full.
"They made a conquest?"—"No, they made a bull."
But softly—what with measures, bulls, and battle,
You must be tir'd with my poor foolish prattle;
But while you look so pleasant, kind and clever,
Had I my way, I'd talk to you for ever.
